articles.title: 'We need some help': 'King Tide' trapping Florida homeowners, flooding streets near Indian River
articles.author: Esther Bower
articles.summary: King Tides caused flooding on Indian River Drive near Cocoa, Florida. It's been a problem for several years. Neighbors think the road needs to be elevated or the shoreline protected with better stabilizers. Brevard County says it's impossible to raise the road due to funding issues.

articles.title: Senate Confirms ‘Sharpiegate' Meteorologist to Lead NOAA
articles.author: Scott Dance
articles.summary: Neil Jacobs has been confirmed as the new leader of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. He was the acting director during the hurricane forecasting controversy of the first Trump administration known as 'Sharpiegate'. He was found to have violated NOAA's code of ethics in 2020 after an investigation into an altered hurricane forecast map President Trump presented in the Oval Office.

articles.title: Hurricane Priscilla triggers warning from U.S. State Department
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Hurricane Priscilla Baja intensifies and prompts the state to suspend classes in Los Cabos and Baja California Sur and La Paz because of the storm. The state does not have any schools in Baja, La Paza and Los Cabo.

articles.title: Scientists ‘resurrected' microbes frozen for thousands of years in Alaska soil
articles.author: Irene Wright
articles.summary: Permafrost is an ice-cold layer of soil and rock that has been frozen for millions of years. In central Alaska, the permafrost reaches hundreds of feet below the tundra. It's the planet's northernmost wilderness, just south of the Arctic circle.

articles.title: Keeping the Ranges grassfire safe
articles.summary: Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) crews are cutting grass on public land in the Murray Goldfields District to reduce the risk of grassfires this summer. Works will take place across Kyneton and Macedon. The works are carefully timed to align with the anticipated increase in grass growth.

articles.title: Climate-driven extreme weather takes bite out of British bread production
articles.author: Dr Ngonidzashe Chirinda
articles.summary: Extreme weather has impacted millions of tonnes of wheat harvest over the past five years. The loss is equivalent to four billion loaves of bread, according to a new report by the International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI). It is due to climate change.

articles.title: Bonaire residents sue the Netherlands over climate inaction
articles.summary: Residents of Bonaire accused the Netherlands of not doing enough to protect them from climate change effects in a Hague courtroom. The case is backed by Greenpeace. The Netherlands presents itself as a climate policy champion, but its lawyers argue it is making strides to combat climate change through emissions reductions and mitigation efforts.

articles.title: Bonaire residents sue Netherlands over climate inaction
articles.summary: Farmer Onnie Emerenciana, a prison guard, and a teacher from Bonaire accuse the Netherlands of not doing enough to protect them from the effects of climate change. The case is being heard at The District Court of The Hague. The Netherlands is making strides to combat climate change, citing greenhouse gas reductions and mitigation efforts.

articles.title: Hurricane Priscilla grows in Pacific as Tropical Storm Jerry forms in east
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: Priscilla is a Category 3 hurricane off the west coast of Mexico. Tropical Storm Jerry formed in the Atlantic Ocean with maximum sustained winds of 50 mph (85 kph) Jerry is expected to strengthen into a hurricane in another day or two. A tropical storm watch is in place for Baja California Sur from Cabo San Lucas to Cabo de San Lazaro due to Hurricane Priscilla.

articles.title: The Devil wears Greta: Trendy performative activism harms Israel, spreads ficition – opinion
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: The Swedish activist rose to infamy for her climate activism, but has now become a mouthpiece for more nefarious causes, writes JPost.com in an opinion piece on The Jerusalem Post. The article is based on a previous version of this article which stated that the author had written that she had written the article.

articles.title: Douglas: Some will wake up to frost tomorrow
articles.author: Paul Douglas
articles.summary: Some suburbs of the Twin Cities will wake up tomorrow to frost for the first time this fall. The Pacific Ocean is experiencing record warmth and warm water is bleeding off into the atmosphere. La Niña Watch is posted into December. If the same 'warm blob' in the Pacific lingers into the winter, it may help to steer more volleys of arctic air into Minnesota.

articles.title: Over 80 WCD households affected by major overtopping
articles.author: INEWS
articles.summary: 85 households along the West Coast Demerara were impacted by significant flooding today. The affected communities stretch from Cornelia Ida through Hague Jib to Fellowship. The Hague Nursery School was also affected, with its entrance completely submerged. The Civil Defence Commission (CDC) and the Neighbourhood Democratic Council (NDC) conducted an initial assessment to determine the extent of the damage.

articles.title: NL-Bonaire-Climate-Case
articles.author: 그런데 이것은 논문입니다
articles.summary: The Netherlands island of Bonaire is at risk of climate change. It is located in the Caribbean Sea. It has a population of about 1.5 million people. It's in the northern part of the Netherlands. It lies on the Atlantic Ocean.

articles.title: Antarctic Circumpolar Current flowed three times faster 130,000 years ago, core samples reveal
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Antarctic Circumpolar Current is Earth's largest oceanic current. It circles around Antarctica from west to east in alignment with Earth's rotation. It is the coldest current in the Earth's system. It's also the largest current in terms of volume.

articles.title: Thousands of homes face flood and erosion threat, Our Marine Environment 2025 finds
articles.author: Ellen O'Dwyer
articles.summary: New Zealand's oceans are warming faster than the global average, marine heatwaves are becoming more frequent and intense, the risk of invasive species and marine disease is increasing with climate change, and wetlands, dunes and native vegetation are being degraded. In 2023, about 219,000 homes worth $180b were located in coastal inundation and inland flood zones. 1300 homes are set to experience greater than 20% damage in one or more extreme events between 2026 and 2060. Thousands of kilometres of roads, water pipes, and buildings worth a combined value of $26.18b were assessed in 2019 as being vulnerable if sea levels rise by 0.6m. Warming seas

articles.title: Priscilla nears major hurricane status in Pacific as new tropical storm swirls in the Atlantic
articles.author: Noaa
articles.summary: Priscilla nears major hurricane status in Pacific. Tropical Storm Jerry has strengthened in the Atlantic Ocean and is heading toward the Caribbean. The U.S. National Hurricane Center reports that Jerry is no longer a tropical storm and is now a tropical depression.

articles.title: Sussex Conservation District advances coastal migration planning
articles.author: Coastal Point • Submitted
articles.summary: Delaware has the lowest average elevation of any U.S. state at 60 feet above sea level. Sea level along the Delaware coast has risen approximately 13 inches in the past century. Projections show an additional rise of 1.6 to 4.9 feet by the year 2100, which could put 8 to 11 percent of the state underwater. More than 60 landowners expressed interest in protecting more than 3,750 acres. To date, more than a dozen landowners have received coastal migration conservation plans, totaling more than 1,000 acres.

articles.title: ‘Heat 2' Moves From Warner Bros. to Amazon MGM as Michael Mann's Sequel Gains Traction
articles.author: Variety
articles.summary: Michael Mann's "Heat 2" is the long-awaited sequel to his 1995 crime drama "Heat" starring Al Pacino and Robert De Niro. It's directed by Michael Mann and stars Robert DeNiro and Pacino. It is out in cinemas now.

articles.title: Missing man last seen in downtown Kelowna, RCMP requesting public's assistance
articles.author: Jordy Cunningham
articles.summary: Cody Nathan Burns, 36, was last seen on Sept. 26 near the 200-block of Leon Avenue. He was reported missing on Oct. 2. The Kelowna RCMP is concerned for his well-being. He is an Indigenous male, about 6'0' tall, medium build, dark brown hair, brown eyes and a moustache and beard.

articles.title: New Zealand's coasts and $180b in assets under threat
articles.summary: $180 billion in assets is at risk in flood prone areas, including 219,000 homes. Climate change is affecting fisheries and aquaculture industries, which contribute over $1 billion to GDP and support more than 14,000 jobs. 266 non-native marine species have established populations here, and wetlands, dunes, and native vegetation are being degraded or replaced.

articles.title: Why Google wants you to ask long, complicated questions
articles.author: AAP Newswire
articles.summary: Artificial intelligence technology is expected to answer more of Australians' burning questions when Google expands its latest web search experiment Down Under. Google is expanding its latest search experiment down under. Google will use artificial intelligence technology to help Australians with their search queries. Google's new search experiment will be called "Artificial Intelligence".

articles.title: Migration alert in effect for Chicago, with thousands of birds filling the skies
articles.author: Matt Stefanski
articles.summary: A significant number of birds are expected to travel through the Chicago area on Tuesday night. Birdcast reports more than 28,000 birds will be in the skies per square kilometer throughout the night. Chicago has adhered to a "Lights Out" program each migration season. It encourages the owners and managers of tall buildings to turn off or dim decorative lights.

articles.title: $180 billion of homes sitting on flood-prone land, government report finds
articles.summary: New Zealand's oceans are warming faster than the global average, marine heatwaves are becoming more frequent and intense, the risk of invasive species and marine disease is increasing with climate change, and wetlands, dunes and native vegtation are being degraded. In 2023, about 219,000 homes worth $180 billion are located in coastal inundation and inland flood zones, and 1300 homes are set to experience greater than 20 percent damage in one or more extreme events between 2026 and 2060. Thousands of kilometres of roads, water pipes, and buildings worth a combined value of $26.18 billion are vulnerable if sea levels rise by 0.6 metres. Cultural and archeological sites

articles.title: Why Trump's purge of ‘negative' national park signs includes climate change
articles.author: Kate Yoder
articles.summary: This summer, park employees and visitors were asked to report any signs that failed to make America look great. Trump's executive order in March directed the Interior Department to remove descriptions that 'inappropriately disparage Americans past or living' and focus instead on 'the greatness of the achievements and progress of the American people' The National Park Service has lost a quarter of its permanent staff due to federal cuts. National parks have warmed at double the rate of the rest of the country.

articles.title: The Devil wears Greta: Trendy performative activism harms Israel, spreads ficition
articles.author: MEMY PEER
articles.summary: The Swedish activist rose to infamy for her climate activism, but has now become a mouthpiece for more nefarious causes. She is now promoting a variety of anti-Muslim and anti-Semitic ideas.       in her new book, "The Truth About It".

articles.title: Billions of Birds Vanishing Across America as Climate Chaos Disrupts Migration — Experts Warn 'We're Next'
articles.author: Justin Price
articles.summary: There are 2.6 billion fewer land birds between autumn and spring migrations compared with the 1970s. Since 1970, North America has lost nearly 3 billion breeding adult birds. The decline signals cascading effects across ecosystems, from crop pollination and seed dispersal to pest control and water quality.

articles.title: Jacksonville has been spending $35K a year on a bridge that isn't open. Where is the money going, and will it reopen?
articles.author: Sophia Vitello
articles.summary: The Duval County portion of George Crady Bridge Fishing Pier remains closed nearly a decade after Hurricane Matthew's devastation. The Nassau County side of the bridge has been fully restored and reopened to the public. Local residents are frustrated because they have to cross county lines to access the functional portion of the Pier. The repair costs are estimated to be around $100 million.

articles.title: Bonaire Residents Sue Netherlands for Climate Inaction
articles.author: -Sathish Raman
articles.summary: Residents of Bonaire have filed a lawsuit against the Netherlands over climate change inaction. They argue that the Dutch government must do more to protect their island from rising temperatures and sea levels. The case is part of a series of global rulings urging governments to protect citizens from climate change. The hearings are set to continue on Wednesday.

articles.title: Bonaire Residents Challenge Dutch Government in Climate Court
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Residents of Bonaire are suing the Netherlands for failing to protect them from climate change. Farmer Onnie Emerenciana traveled thousands of miles to share his experiences of drought and heat. The Netherlands defends its climate strategies, pointing to greenhouse gas reductions. The ongoing hearings could echo prior landmark rulings demanding decisive climate action.

articles.title: Nine To Noon for Wednesday 8 October 2025 Nine To Noon
articles.summary: $180 billion in assets are at risk in flood prone areas of New Zealand due to climate change. The Ministry of Transport is reviewing penalties for traffic offences for the first time in 26 years. A lobby group in New Zealand is working to create a Wellbeing Economy Alliance Aotearoa to improve government decision-making.

articles.title: Nigel Farage's Reform compared to 1930s fascists by Michael Heseltine in scathing attack
articles.author: The Mirror
articles.summary: Michael Heseltine has likened Nigel Farage's Reform UK to fascist groups of the 1930s and Kemi Badenoch's climate change plans to Tory grandee Michael Heseltines' Michael. Heseltins has also lashed out at Kemi's 'unforgivable' climate change plan.

articles.title: Arizona will have 4 of the hottest U.S. counties in 2050: Study
articles.author: Phoenix New Times
articles.summary: Maricopa, Yuma, La Paz and Pinal counties will be four of the five hottest counties in the U.S. by 2050, according to a Cotality study. The study was based on data from the Global Warming Policy Foundation.

articles.title: Hurricane Priscilla Los Cabos tourists shelter as seas rise
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Hurricane Priscilla Baja intensifies and prompts the state to suspend classes in Los Cabos and Baja California Sur and La Paz because of the storm. The state does not have any schools in Baja, La Paza and Los Cabo.

articles.title: Australian spy chief Andrew Shearer sounds alarm over 'day-to-day coercion' designed to make world 'safer for authoritarianism'
articles.author: Max Melzer
articles.summary: Andrew Shearer, Australia's top spy chief, has warned the world has entered a space between genuine peace and overt war as authoritarian states seek to reshape the global order in their favour. SkyNews.com.au streaming subscription gives you access to breaking news and live interviews from politicians and experts.

articles.title: Fall bird migration is underway
articles.author: Submitted content
articles.summary: This is the ideal time of year for New York residents and visitors to head to Bird Conservation Areas across the state for great bird watching opportunities. Every spring and fall, thousands of raptors migrate, so birders may see or hear eagles, kestrels, sharp-shinned hawks, ospreys, broad-winged hawks and peregrine falcons.

articles.title: Ghana: Integrate Climate, Devt Policies in National Planning
articles.author: Benedicta GYIMAAH FOLLEY
articles.summary: The International Organisation for Migration (IOM) Ghana urges the government and policymakers to integrate climate and development policies into national and local planning frameworks to effectively address the growing challenges of climate-induced mobility in the country. The research focused on four climate-vulnerable communities within the Accra Metropolitan Assembly (AMA) where flooding, poor drainage systems, and sea-level rise continue to endanger lives and livelihoods. Women and youth in informal settlements remained the most affected.

articles.title: Meteorologist Slams The Guardian: Urban Heat, Not CO2, Driving City Temperature Rises
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: The Guardian published an article claiming that global warming has caused a sharp rise in the number of extremely hot days in cities worldwide. The data suggests that the significant rise in measured temperatures in and around major cities is due to the Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect. Urbanization is a major driver of observed warming at city weather stations.

articles.title: Human behaviour and the environment: The connection
articles.author: FT Online
articles.summary: The focus is often on technology, new policies and big investments, but human behaviour is often overlooked. Our actions, big and small, add up to protect or harm the planet, and we need to focus on what people do every day at home, at work, and in communities.

articles.title: Daily Memo: Migratory Changes A Factor In Rising Southeast Asian Birdstrikes
articles.author: Adrian Schofield
articles.summary: Climate change is influencing birdstrike trends at Southeast Asian airports. Other more localized factors at hubs like Manila are also increasing bird hazards for airlines in this region. 'Climate change certainly has been changing the migratory patterns' of birds and changing the bird migration patterns.

articles.title: National Academies' Climate Report: Another Tale Of Climate Change Bias
articles.author: Steven E. Koonin
articles.summary: The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine released a report on the effect of greenhouse-gas emissions on the U.S. well-being last month. The report was meant to bolster the scientific basis for the Environmental Protection Agency's 2009 finding. However, the report deceptively shapes its discussion of the models used to project climatic changes. It doesn't shy away from subjects that contradict a Grimm perspective.

articles.title: Birds are behaving strangely — and it could have dire implications for humanity, scientist warns
articles.author: nypost
articles.summary: Climate change is disrupting bird migration patterns and affecting avian ecosystems across the globe. Red Knot, Swainson's Thrush, and Black-throated Blue Warblers in the US have been affected by shifting migration patterns. Ornithologists suggest that we can help birds during their migration marathon by switching off the lights at night and setting out bird feeders and baths.

articles.title: Truth and Freedom in the Age of Science
articles.author: Jeffrey A. Tucker
articles.summary: As a kid, I had a recurring nightmare about being chased by a woolly mammoth. The school told him that a new ice age was coming and that woolly mammoths dominated the last age and they will be everywhere again. He believes this is a good idea.

articles.title: Birds are behaving strangely — and it could have dire implications for humanity, scientist warns
articles.author: Ben Cost
articles.summary: Climate change is disrupting bird migration patterns. It's affecting avian ecosystems across the globe like an apocalyptic butterfly effect. Red Knots, a shorebird that stops over in the US while migrating from the Arctic to South America, have seen their populations decline by around 75% due to various factors. About 389 North American bird species will become extinct within the next 50 years.

articles.title: Estero wants resident input on flood vulnerabilities
articles.author: Mike Walcher
articles.summary: Estero invites residents to a workshop on Wednesday, October 8th, at the recreation center on Corkscrew Road. The workshop begins at 5 p.m. and runs until 6:30. Residents can submit comments about flood threats or other hazards in Estero.

articles.title: Tiny Caribbean island accuses Netherlands of failing to protect it from climate change
articles.author: Molly Quell
articles.summary: Residents from the Dutch Caribbean island of Bonaire have launched legal action against the Netherlands, accusing the nation of failing to adequately protect them from the escalating impacts of climate change. A farmer, a prison guard, and a teacher testified in a Hague courtroom on Tuesday, in a case supported by environmental group Greenpeace. The case is being heard at the District Court of The Hague, where the landmark Urgenda proceedings began more than a decade ago, and in 2019, the Dutch Supreme Court ruled in favor of climate activists.

articles.title: Ghana urged to establish culture of resilience to tackle climate change
articles.author: emmakd
articles.summary: Dr Godfred Seidu Jasaw is the Chairman of the Parliamentary Select Committee on Food, Agriculture and Cocoa Affairs. He was speaking at the opening ceremony of a two-day National Validation Workshop organised by AGRA and Mathematica in Accra. It was on climate vulnerability mapping and climate change risk analysis for guiding climate adaptation interventions and investments in Ghana, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and Zambia.

articles.title: Sea defence funding is 'most important thing council will ever do'
articles.summary: 90% of East Coast sea defences between Saltfleet and Gibraltar Point are expected to fail by 2040. The total cost of replacing them is estimated to be billions of pounds. Lincolnshire County Council and East Lindsey District Council will share just under £1m for the proposal, with the Environment Agency contributing around £3m. The sea defences in the area protect 20,000 homes and 38,000 static caravans.

articles.title: ‘Solar maximum': More storms from the sun could bring more Northern Lights, potential power grid, technology disruptions
articles.author: Frank Olsen
articles.summary: The sun is at the height of a cycle which sees its north and south poles flip approximately every 11 years. More of the world, including parts of the continental U.S., could see increased instances of Aurora Borealis lights over the next several months.

articles.title: Economic opportunity of climate action a focus as Toronto Climate Week launches
articles.author: Ian Bickis
articles.summary: Canada has an opportunity to reap the economic gains of climate action as the U.S. retreats, said speakers at the launch of the first Toronto Climate Week on Wednesday. Climate change is already hurting the economy, said federal Environment Minister Julie Dabrusin, citing a study that estimated climate-induced damages would cause a $25 billion drag on the economy this year. The government is working on its climate competitiveness strategy, but there are concerns about how slow it's been.

articles.title: Sea level rise could plunge 100 MILLION buildings underwater, warn scientists – so, is your home at risk?
articles.author: WILIAM HUNTER
articles.summary: Rising sea levels could plunge more than 100 million buildings underwater by 2100, according to scientists from McGill University in Montreal. The researchers focused their analysis on the Global South - the bottom half of the world comprising Africa, Southeast Asia and Central and South America. They created a map showing what flooding would look like worldwide.

articles.title: Bonaire residents sue the Netherlands over climate inaction
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Farmer Onnie Emerenciana traveled 4,000 miles to testify in court on behalf of Bonaire residents who accuse the Netherlands of not doing enough to protect them from climate change. The case was heard in a Hague court on Tuesday and backed by Greenpeace.

articles.title: Canada, U.S. lose $2.9B in wheat crops, climate change fueling diseases
articles.author: Cheryl Santa Maria
articles.summary: Diseases cost Canadian and U.S. wheat producers US$2.9 billion between 2018 and 2021. The losses are linked to nearly 30 diseases, with fusarium head blight, stripe rust, and leaf rust coming out as the top three pathogens. 2019 was the worst year observed, with 188 bushels lost to disease. Canada's agricultural industry employed 2.3 million people and generated about $150 billion annually.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Jerry forms, expected to remain at sea
articles.author: Matthew Huddleston
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Jerry has formed in the central tropical Atlantic. Jerry is forecast to become a hurricane by Wednesday evening. Jerry poses no threat to the east coast of the United States, but it could come close to Bermuda later this week and then turn back into the open Atlantic.

articles.title: Thousands of ladybirds spotted flooding Worcestershire homes
articles.author: Kieran Williams
articles.summary: Thousands of ladybirds have been spotted in Worcestershire homes since Monday (October 6). The warmer-than-average temperatures were the catalyst for the ladybirds to migrate. Ladybirds are harmless, but people should keep them away from the inside of their homes.

articles.title: Snow and Rain Create Havoc Across Himachal Pradesh
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Snow has blanketed the higher reaches of Himachal Pradesh for the third consecutive day. The tribal districts of Lahaul and Spiti recorded heavy snowfall, while the Pangi area in Chamba experienced its first snowfall of the season. The region has already recorded 625% excess rainfall compared to the average for this time of the year.

articles.title: Hurricane Priscilla: Baja shuts schools in Los Cabos and La Paz
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Hurricane Priscilla Baja intensifies and prompts the state to suspend classes in Los Cabos and La Paz on October 7. Heavy rain and dangerous surf are forecast along the Pacific coast of Baja, with heavy rain and heavy surf forecast along Pacific coast.

articles.title: Flood alerts issued for West Norfolk, including King's Lynn, Hunstanton and surrounding areas as residents told to ‘be prepared'
articles.author: Alice Hobbs
articles.summary: Flood alerts have been issued for the West Norfolk coast. Water could rise as high as 0.13m above predicted tide levels between 6.30am and 8:30am tomorrow morning. North-westerly winds of up to 18mph are also expected.

articles.title: National Climate Change Office leads National Climate Change Adaptation Workshop
articles.author: BBNTEAM
articles.summary: The National Climate Change Office is hosting a multisectoral workshop to validate Belize's National Adaptation Plan (NAP) Gap, Vulnerability, and Risk Assessment from October 6-7, 2025. Participants are reviewing assessment findings and identifying key adaptation measures for priority sectors, including agriculture, tourism, health, forestry, land use, and infrastructure.

articles.title: Kenya's slum-dwellers are struggling to survive on the climate crisis frontline
articles.author: Nick Ferris
articles.summary: Jen lives in Kawangare, one of the many 'informal settlements' – or slums – in Kenya's capital Nairobi. The droughts and flood events that hit her neighbourhood are becoming more regular and intense due to climate change. Food inflation has been rampant in recent years. The growing frequency of flood events is also increasing the risk of water-borne diseases.

articles.title: Half of America's Beaches Could Vanish by 2100 -- Here's What's Working to Save Them
articles.author: Surfrider Foundation
articles.summary: Surfrider Foundation's 2025 State of the Beach Report reveals climate crisis impacts and proven nature-based strategies protecting coastlines from California to Puerto Rico. More than half of America's sandy beaches will be lost by 2100 due to climate-driven sea level rise.

articles.title: Media and political attacks on Australia's emissions targets ‘straight out of the climate obstruction playbook', expert says
articles.author: Graham Readfearn
articles.summary: In recent months Australia has seen political and media attacks on renewable energy and climate action. Prof Christian Downie studied the techniques used by business groups and lobbyists all over the world to undermine warnings of the risks of climate change and slow the global transition away from fossil fuels. Business Council of Australia released widely reported modelling as Albanese government prepared to set its 2035 climate target. Australian scientists who prepared the country's first national climate risk assessment were accused of scaremongering by a fellow at a US-based thinktank. Trade associations working on climate in the US had spent US$3.4bn in a decade on political activities, including lobbying, PR campaigns and political donations.

articles.title: Caribbean island residents ask court to order Dutch state to take climate action
articles.author: Jee Geronimo
articles.summary: Greenpeace Netherlands and residents of Bonaire want the Netherlands to take more measures to protect the island against the effects of climate change. The case is one of the first to test the obligations set in a landmark European climate ruling and this year's World Court opinion on a national level.

articles.title: Mongolia records warmest September since 1940
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Mongolia reported its warmest September in 2025 since temperature records began, the National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring said on October 7th. The weather in Mongolia has been warm since the beginning of the 20th century, the agency said.

articles.title: It's Too Hot Here Say Islanders.
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Residents of Bonaire, a small Caribbean island, have taken the Dutch government to court, saying climate change is making their lives unbearable. They want the Dutch state to reach net zero emissions by 2040, ten years sooner than current plans. Lawyer for the state says such policy decisions belong to elected governments, not courts.

articles.title: Bonaire residents ask court to order Dutch state to take climate action
articles.author: Staff Editor
articles.summary: Residents of Bonaire in the Caribbean are asking a court to order the Dutch state to cut greenhouse gases more quickly. They want the Netherlands to cut its net greenhouse gas emissions to zero by 2040, 10 years ahead of its current plans. They say the Dutch government has not done enough to protect the island against rising sea levels.

articles.title: Bonaire residents sue the Netherlands over climate inaction
articles.author: Molly Quell
articles.summary: Farmer Onnie Emerenciana, a prison guard, and a teacher from Bonaire accuse the Netherlands of not doing enough to protect them from the effects of climate change. The case, backed by Greenpeace, follows a series of international landmark rulings that found governments have broad obligations to protect their citizens from increasing temperatures and rising sea levels. The Netherlands is making strides to combat climate change, citing greenhouse gas reductions and mitigation efforts.

articles.title: Bonaire residents sue the Netherlands over climate inaction
articles.summary: Bonaire residents accuse the Netherlands of not doing enough to protect them from climate change. The case is backed by Greenpeace. It follows a series of international landmark rulings that found governments have broad obligations to protect their citizens from increasing temperatures and rising sea levels.

articles.title: Climate change as threat to migratory species across board
articles.author: Helen Oji
articles.summary: The Migratory Species and Climate Change Expert workshop gathered 73 experts from around the world in Edinburgh, UK to discuss the impact of climate change on migratory species. The report details how climate change disruption is affecting migratory animals across the board, altering ranges, shrinking habitats, and threatening ecosystem service delivery.

articles.title: How Sri Lanka protects Tamil Nadu, Andhra Pradesh from ocean fury
articles.author: V. Geetanath
articles.summary: Sri Lanka acts as a land barrier to protect the southeastern coast of India from long-period swell waves generated in the Southern Ocean. The eastern coast, especially Tamil Nadu and southern Andhra Pradesh, remains largely unaffected. The study has implications in the context of global sea level rise and climate change.

articles.title: Where did the ‘global cooling' myth come from?
articles.author: Corinne Iozzio
articles.summary: There was a time when some scientists warned of "global cooling" in the 1970s. Today, 99% of climate scientists agree that the world is warming. Human-caused climate change is having a cooling effect in the upper parts of the atmosphere. The same gases that make us cook are pulling down temperatures higher up.

articles.title: First handful of geese spotted migrating south at Freezout Lake Wildlife Management Area
articles.author: NBC Montana Staff
articles.summary: The first light geese were spotted at Freezout Lake Wildlife Management Area this week. The waterfowl numbers on the WMA are low due to the ongoing drought. The fall migration usually peaks in early November, with an average of 12,000 birds pushing through on peak days.

articles.title: 100 million buildings across Africa, Asia and America face threat from rising seas
articles.author: Interesting Engineering
articles.summary: If we don't curb fossil fuel emissions, sea level rise could put more than 100 million buildings at risk of routine flooding, according to a new study led by McGill University in Canada. Sea level rise is a slow, but unstoppable consequence of warming that is already impacting coastal populations and will continue for centuries.

articles.title: Ominous warning issued for humans as birds suddenly develop 'unsettling' behaviour
articles.author: Emilia Randall
articles.summary: Birds are not following their usual migration patterns as global warming throws off the temperature queues. Several bird species in the US have already been affected by this changing behavior, including the Black-throated Blue Warbler, Red Knot, and Swainson's Thrush. Red Knots have seen their populations decline by 75%.

articles.title: A celestial ballet: How are the Northern Lights formed?
articles.author: Divya Vinayak Patilkulkarni
articles.summary: Northern lights, or aurora borealis, can be seen near the northern hemisphere. Southern lights, aurora australis, can also be seen in the southern hemisphere. Most auroras happen 97-1,000 km above Earth's surface. Most active auroras are when the solar wind is the strongest.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg A23a may vanish by late 2025
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: A23a, once the largest and longest-lasting iceberg on Earth, is breaking apart. Since calving in 1986, A23a has remained grounded in the Weddell Sea for more than 30 years. Around 2020, the iceberg began drifting northward due to ice melt and other processes.

articles.title: Australian teachers face staffing shortages while OECD report shows high stress on the rise
articles.summary: Sky News contributor Joe Hildebrand discusses how Australian teachers are the second most stressed out teachers in the world according to a study from the OECD. 'Staggering, but not surprising,' he says. 'Teachers are among the world's most stressed people'

articles.title: Birds are behaving strangely — and it could have dire implications for humanity
articles.author: Ben Cost
articles.summary: Climate change is disrupting bird migration patterns. The effect is affecting avian ecosystems across the globe. Red Knots, Swainson's Thrush and Black-throated Blue Warblers have seen their populations decline due to dwindling food supplies on their migration route from North America to the Caribbean. The National Audubon Society has warned 389 North American bird species will become extinct within the next half-century.

articles.title: What are Milankovitch Cycles?
articles.author: Vaishnavi Gopinath
articles.summary: Milankovitch cycles are caused by changes in the Earth's orbit around the sun and its angle and axis. The change in its orbit affects the distribution of sunlight and the solar energy for Earth to absorb. It is also responsible for the start of the ice age. The cycle is composed of eccentricity, obliquity and precession.

articles.title: UPDATED: Wildland blaze an estimated 5 hectares in size near Gravenhurst did not grow overnight, say fire officials
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: The Beiers Road wildland fire did not grow overnight. Crews are working to overhaul the area and extinguish pockets of deep seated burning with several hectares still smoldering. The road is closed in the area. Water tanker shuttle is underway. Gravenhurst Fire Station is filling.

articles.title: Climate Change Linked to 100000 Heatwave Deaths Global Study
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: 2023 heatwaves caused 178,486 excess deaths worldwide, equivalent to 23 deaths per million. Southern Europe recorded the highest 2023 heatwave death rate at 120 per million, followed by Eastern and Western Europe. Human activities have been the main driver of climate change since the 1800s.

articles.title: ‘Staggering but not surprising': Aussie teachers named second most stressed in the world
articles.summary: Teachers in Australia are the second most stressed out in the world, according to the OECD. They spend less than half of their time in the classroom.    Joe Hildebrand is a Sky News contributor and a teacher's union leader. He talks about the study.

articles.title: Rising seas endanger 100 million buildings in Global South: Report
articles.author: Mrigakshi Dixit
articles.summary: If we don't curb fossil fuel emissions, sea level rise could put more than 100 million buildings at risk of regular flooding in regions of Africa, Southeast Asia and Central and South America. Even the most ambitious emissions cuts could lead to a rise of just 0.5 meters (1.6 feet) and still inundate 3 million buildings.

articles.title: Marine heatwaves to become more frequent off UK and Irish coasts, experts say
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: There is a 10% chance that similar events to the 'unheard of' temperatures in 2023 could occur each year, according to the research. Scientists warn such events will happen more often in the future due to climate change. The unprecedented marine heatwave of 2023 was in line with climate modelling.

articles.title: ‘What on earth is wrong with Australia?' Israel furious at pro-Hamas graffiti in Melbourne
articles.summary: 'What on earth is wrong with Australia?' asks Israel. Israel is angry at pro-Hamas graffiti in Melbourne, Australia.    in response to the graffiti in Israel's capital, Melbourne, being painted with Hamas' symbols and symbols of terror in recent days.

articles.title: NAB To Face Australia's First Bank Shareholder Resolution On Nature Risk
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Concerned NAB shareholders will file Australia's first bank shareholder resolution on deforestation today. The resolution will go to NAB's annual meeting on 12 December. It calls on the bank to stop financing deforestation and to set a strategy to stop deforestation in line with global standards.

articles.title: Red Sea faced severe dried out conditions around 6.2 million years ago
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: The Red Sea completely dried out 6.2 million years ago. This event is linked to the Messinian Salinity Crisis. The Red Sea's desiccation occurred when its connection to other oceans was restricted. The Mediterranean Zanclean flood occurred nearly a million years after the reflooding of the Red Sea.

articles.title: Earth's long-term monitoring programs are in peril (Opinion)
articles.author: Pieter P. Tans
articles.summary: Dave Keeling made the first accurate measurements of atmospheric CO2 in 1956. NOAA began its own measurements in 1967 at a site on Niwot Ridge operated by CU-Boulder's Mountain Research Station. In 1972, NOAA founded the Geophysical Monitoring for Climatic Change program. The current budget proposal calls for the elimination of NOAA's climate and weather research programs.

articles.title: Hurricane Priscilla Strengthens to Category 2 Storm
articles.summary: Priscilla has strengthened to a Category 2 hurricane off the Pacific coast of Mexico. It has maximum sustained winds of 100 mph (155 kph) and is moving northwest at 10 mph (17 kph). A tropical storm watch is in place for Baja California Sur from Cabo San Lucas to Córdoba San Lazaro.

articles.title: Warm weather, lack of rain slowing salmon run in GTA streams
articles.author: Lucas Casaletto
articles.summary: The annual salmon migration is underway across the Greater Toronto Area. The TRCA says the salmon run can continue into late October, depending on weather patterns. Conservation officials encourage residents to visit local rivers and streams to witness the migration, but remind the public to observe from a distance and avoid disturbing the fish.

articles.title: Marine heat wave ‘unprecedented but not unexpected'
articles.author: Finya Swai
articles.summary: In June 2023, ocean temperatures climbed nearly 3 degrees Celsius above normal off northern Europe. The record-breaking marine heat wave was 'unprecedented but not unexpected' in a rapidly warming climate, according to Jamie Atkins, a climate scientist at Utrecht University.

articles.title: Caribbean island residents ask court to order Dutch state to take climate action
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Residents of the Dutch-Caribbean island of Bonaire are asking a court to order the Dutch state to cut greenhouse gases more quickly. They want the Netherlands to cut its net greenhouse gas emissions to zero by 2040, 10 years ahead of its current plans. They say the Dutch government has not done enough to protect the island against rising sea levels.

articles.title: Inequality fuels climate crisis: EU countries among those responsible
articles.author: Liam Gilliver
articles.summary: Hot or Cool Institute analysed the lifestyle carbon footprint for 25 countries. It found that high-income countries must slash their average lifestyle emissions by 82 to 94%. Italy is the worst polluter, with lifestyle emissions 7.5 times higher than climate goals require, followed by Germany, Portugal, and Estonia. Greece has the lowest emissions within the high- income bracket, but is still exceeding targets by over five times.

articles.title: Deforestation Can Cause Eight-fold Increase In Flood Event Risk, Says Report
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: New research based on forest fires in Australia proves there is a significantly higher risk of large-scale flooding when major deforestation has occurred in catchment areas.    .   ...   "There is a much higher risk" of flooding when there is major deforestation.

articles.title: France's Wine Output Dips Amid August Heatwave
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The French Ministry of Agriculture has revised its wine production forecast for this year, reducing it to 36 million hectolitres. This represents a 1% drop compared to last year's harvest. The ministry indicated that the revision stems from a severe heatwave experienced in August, which adversely affected grape ripening and limited growth.

articles.title: Alarming Alert for Humanity: Birds Display ‘Disturbing' New Habits
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Birds in the US are changing their migration patterns due to warmer conditions in their wintering areas. Audubon Society warned 389 North American bird species will become vulnerable to extinction within the next 50 years. About 3 billion birds in North America have been lost since 1970 due to climate change.

articles.title: 2023 Ocean Heatwave: Unprecedented Intensity Yet Scientifically Anticipated
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: June 2023 saw a 2.9°C rise above the long-term June average sea surface temperature in shallow waters bordering the UK, including the North Sea and the Celtic Sea. Scientists from the University of Exeter, the Met Office, and Cefas analysed the extreme event. They found that such heatwaves are becoming more frequent due to ongoing anthropogenic influences.

articles.title: ‘Led by fools': Warnings China is seeking to divide and distract Australians
articles.summary: Sky News host James Macpherson says Australia may be 'led by fools' with fresh warnings China is trying to distract and divide Australians. He claims China is seeking to distract, divide and distract Australians.       "Australia may be led by fools".

articles.title: Marine heatwaves to become more frequent off UK and Irish coasts, experts say
articles.author: Helena Horton
articles.summary: The unprecedented marine heatwave of 2023 was in line with climate modelling, as scientists warn such events will become more frequent. The heatwave off the UK and Irish coasts during a summer of 40C temperatures raised concerns that fish, shellfish and kelp would not be able to survive.

articles.title: La Niña could influence winter weather in Connecticut. Here's the latest outlook.
articles.author: Dan Amarante
articles.summary: A La Niña Watch is in effect globally, with a high likelihood of this large-scale climate phenomenon arriving during the upcoming winter. Long-term trends support warmer-than-normal conditions across the Northeast. Weak La Nina conditions tend to deliver above-normal snowfall in the Northeast, but drought in New England could limit the amount of snowfall.

articles.title: Hauraki Marine Bill A Huge Step Despite Govt Backtrack
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: The Hauraki Gulf is on the brink of ecological collapse. Having these protections in place is a step towards revitalising the life-sustaining capacity of the Gulf now and for future generations. The science is clear that the Gulf is at risk of collapse.

articles.title: Cyclone Shakhti likely to weaken into Depression in 12 hours
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: The cyclonic storm 'Shakhti' over west-central Arabian Sea has been located at 960km southwest of Karachi. Sea condition is likely to remain high to very rough over the same region with squally winds 45-55 gusting 65Km/hour into deep sea. Fishermen have been advised not to venture into the deep sea during next 12 hours.

articles.title: ‘So angry, so crazy': Donald Trump says Greta Thunberg should 'see a doctor'; activists land in Greece after Israel deportation
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Greta Thunberg and 170 other activists were deported from Israel after being detained while participating in an aid flotilla bound for Gaza. US President Donald Trump called her angry and suggested she seek medical help as she has an anger management problem. He called it a genocide.

articles.title: Earth Talk: Global warming and eye problems?
articles.author: Earthtalk
articles.summary: Rising global temperatures, worsening air quality, shifting disease patterns and increasing water scarcity are contributing factors that heighten the risk of eye-related problems worldwide. Wearing sunglasses that block ultraviolet rays and reducing exposure to polluted air can lessen irritation and disease risk. Stricter air quality regulations, programs that expand access to safe water and greater public awareness of climate change's hidden health impacts all play essential roles.

articles.title: Integrate climate, devt policies in national planning
articles.author: Admin1
articles.summary: The International Organisation for Migration (IOM) Ghana has urged the government and policymakers to integrate climate and development policies into national and local planning frameworks to effectively address the growing challenges of climate-induced mobility in the country. The call follows a recent IOM-led study conducted in partnership with the Accra Metropolitan Assembly (AMA) as part of a wider research initiative undertaken in Accra, Addis Ababa, and Bujumbura to examine the impacts of climate change on human mobility across Africa.

articles.title: Distribution of Indonesian Upland Rice Farmers Affected by Climate Change in 2024  Pusat Data Ekonomi dan Bisnis Indonesia
articles.author: databoks.katadata.co.id
articles.summary: Single Data Premium costs Rp300.000 150.000 - Rp50.000 /month Hanya Rp833 per artikel. Read the article immediately 'Distribution of Indonesian Upland Rice Farmers Affected by Climate Change in 2024'.

articles.title: Bridging the Climate Divide with Youth Led Solutions
articles.author: Suha Farook
articles.summary: Sri Lankan youth are at a turning point in their lives. They need to focus on climate change education, support nature-based solutions, give youth a real voice in local decision-making and unlock micro grants to help good ideas grow. They also need to teach climate and green skills in schools, support mangrove restoration and hillside reforestation, and support grassroots groups.

articles.title: Extreme Weather Costs: Silver Medal We Don't Want
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: New data from Munich Re's NatCatSERVICE global database shows that for most of the last 45 years Australia has ranked second only behind the United States for economic and insured losses per capita. In the last five years New Zealand came into third place. The Report highlights policy recommendations that will help Australia adapt to our physical climate risks.

articles.title: Climate trigger ‘ruled out' of Labor's re-write of environmental laws, says Murray Watt
articles.author: The West Australian
articles.summary: Murray Watt has ruled out the use of a 'climate trigger' in Australia's new environmental laws. Activists have long called for the legal mechanism to be added to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act to specifically protect from the wider effects of climate change. The revised Act is scheduled to be considered in Parliament by the end of the year.

articles.title: Greenpeace in court over Dutch failure to protect Bonaire
articles.author: Robin Pascoe
articles.summary: Greenpeace is taking the Dutch government to court on Tuesday over its lack of action to protect the Caribbean island of Bonaire from rising sea levels. In January last year, eight people from the former Dutch colony joined forces with Greenpeace to sue the government for failing to protect them against climate change. It is now 10 years since the start of the Urgenda climate court case.

articles.title: Australian state says pro-Palestine event on Oct 7 anniversary
articles.author: Hong Kong Standard
articles.summary: Australia is a country of people living in the Middle East. It is mainly populated by people from Australia. It has a population of about 1.5 billion people. It's a nation of people. Its main territory is called Australia. Its population is mainly consists of people from that country.

articles.title: Dengue cases surge across Bangladesh as experts call for urgent action
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: Climate change has extended the breeding season for mosquitoes, which is bad news for them.       in the UK. In the U.S. it's good news for the birds.  in Australia it's bad for the bees.

articles.title: Rising temperatures and extreme weather endanger wildlife migration
articles.author: Mail Guardian South Africa
articles.summary: Climate change is affecting migratory species worldwide, changing their ranges, shrinking habitats and reducing the benefits that people get from nature. Migratory species are vital in maintaining healthy ecosystems that are resilient and contribute to climate change mitigation, according to the UNFCCC.

articles.title: Climate change caused nearly 100,000 deaths from heatwaves in 2023: Global study
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: Unprecedented heatwaves in 2023 caused 178,486 excess deaths worldwide, equivalent to 23 deaths per million, with more than half attributable to manmade climate change. Heatwave-related deaths were concentrated in subtropical and temperate zones of the Northern Hemisphere.

articles.title: Near-record heat sparks fire alerts across Darwin and Top End
articles.summary: Darwin Airport recorded its second-highest temperature in history on October 4 at 38.4C. The airport recorded its highest ever maximum of 38.9C on October 18, 1982. The extreme heat brought scores of fires at the weekend, with 22 fire alerts sent out. A severe heatwave warning is in place for the Tiwi District for Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

articles.title: Climate change linked to nearly 100,000 heatwave deaths in 2023: study
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: 2023's unprecedented heatwaves were linked to human-induced climate change, according to an Australian-led global study. Unprecedented heatwaves in 2023 caused an estimated 178,486 excess deaths worldwide, equivalent to 23 deaths per year. There is an urgent need for adaptive public health interventions and climate mitigation strategies to reduce future mortality burdens.

articles.title: Claim: Politicians Don't Know 2025 Must Be Peak Fossil Fuel
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: University of East Anglia academics surveyed British MPs and members of the public on the urgency of peaking global greenhouse gas emissions. Less than 15% of those surveyed could identify the deadline correctly. Politicians and the public need to understand the scale of the climate crisis and how urgent it is.

articles.title: Climate trigger ruled out of nature law reforms
articles.summary: Environment minister rules out a climate change assessment under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. Environment Minister Murray Watt has promised to introduce new EPBC Act by the end of 2025. The government needs the support of the Greens or the coalition to pass the laws.

articles.title: Climate trigger ruled out of nature law reforms
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The reworked environmental laws will not include a climate trigger, the federal environment minister has confirmed. The law will not be changed to include such a trigger, he added.       in Australia's new environmental laws, which are to be introduced soon.

articles.title: Climate trigger ruled out of nature law reforms
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Environment Minister Murray Watt rules out a climate change assessment under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC) Act. The Samuel review declared the EPBC Act ineffective and outdated, falling short in nature protection and business certainty. The government needs the support of the Greens or the coalition to pass the laws and a deal has not been struck.

articles.title: Ominous warning for humanity as birds suddenly adopt 'unsettling' behavior
articles.author: CHRIS MELORE
articles.summary: Birds in the US are delaying their migration because of warmer temperatures in their winter habitats. The National Audubon Society warned 389 North American bird species will become vulnerable to extinction within the next 50 years. The main driver of this mass extinction event was found to be birds losing their living spaces.

articles.title: Marine heatwaves found to impact ocean food webs, carbon cycle
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Marine heatwaves can reshape ocean food webs and slow the flow of carbon from surface waters to the deep sea, undermining one of the ocean's key roles in buffering climate change. The Gulf of Alaska experienced two major marine heatwaves in recent years, the so-called 'Blob' from 2013 to 2015 and another from 2019 to 2020. Each event alters plankton lineages differently, which affects how carbon is cycled. The Indian Ocean is already contending with warming trends.

articles.title: Brevard County Monitors Beach Erosion as High Winds, Tides Continue
articles.author: Tidal amplitude
articles.summary: Erosion along the Brevard County coastline is expected to continue through Wednesday. The most visible impacts are expected in the Mid Reach and South Beaches project areas, where beaches are currently at their narrowest. The next scheduled beach nourishment project for Mid Reach area is anticipated in approximately three years.

articles.title: 'See A Doctor': Greta EXPLODES Against West, Trump Fires Back Amid Fight Over Israel-Gaza Flotilla
articles.summary: After Israeli crackdown on Gaza Flotilla, U.S. President Donald Trump has again lashed out at climate activist Greta Thunberg. Trump claims she's 'no longer into the environment' and accuses her of being 'so angry and crazy' and suggests she should see a doctor.

articles.title: Eastern Australian humpback whale population now well above pre-whaling levels, report finds
articles.author: Belinda Smith
articles.summary: There are more than 50,000 eastern Australian humpback whales in 2024. That's 20,000 more individuals than the estimated pre-whaling population of the early 1900s. Eastern Australian humpbacks were hunted almost to extinction by whalers for their oil. The International Whaling Commission banned whaling in the Southern Hemisphere in 1963. The population rose to around 1,000 individuals in the 1990s and into the 2000s.

articles.title: Breaking: Bird Fire reported in Tulare County on Oct. 6
articles.author: CA WILDFIRE BOT
articles.summary: A new wildfire was reported today at 6:05 p.m. in Tulare County, California. Bird Fire has been burning on private land. There is no update on the containment progress of the fire and its cause has not yet been determined. This story was originally published October 6, 2025 at 6.36 PM.

articles.title: Victoria scientists chart climate change from Antarctica
articles.author: Jordan Cunningham
articles.summary: Team Canada set sail to Antarctica last February on a Canadian vessel with the Royal Canadian Navy to study how glaciers are responding to a rapidly changing climate. Canada installed its own coastal observatory on the frozen continent a few years ago. Ocean Networks Canada, based in Victoria, transmits data collected from beneath the ice to a lab on Vancouver Island.

articles.title: Researchers sound alarm over controversial plan to block ocean currents: 'Unlikely to be socially acceptable'
articles.author: Susan Elizabeth Turek
articles.summary: Researchers sound alarm over controversial plan to block ocean currents: 'Unlikely to be socially acceptable' Could geoengineering save coastal communities from rising sea levels? Researchers warn one proposal gaining steam could leave them worse off than they were to begin with. The 10 warmest years on record have occurred over the past 10 years.

articles.title: The Pacific Ocean is overheated, making fall feel like summer
articles.author: CBC.ca
articles.summary: The Pacific Ocean is overheated, making fall feel like summer in parts of Canada. A massive heat wave in the northern Pacific Ocean likely to be the reason for the unusually warm temperatures across parts of the country, experts say. It's October 7th 2025.

articles.title: Cyclone Shakti likely to weaken into depression today
articles.author: M. Waqar Bhatti
articles.summary: Cyclone Shakti has developed over the west central and adjoining northwest Arabian Sea. It is expected to weaken into a depression within the next 12 hours. The sea condition remains high to very rough with squally winds reaching 45 to 55 kilometres per hour and gusting up to 65 km per hour in the deep sea. The department advised fishermen not to venture into the open sea until Monday morning.

articles.title: The Guardian Is Wrong: Cities Are Hotter Because of the UHI Effect, Not Increased CO₂
articles.author: Anthony Watts
articles.summary: In The Guardian's op-ed, they assert that global warming has caused a sharp rise in the number of extremely hot days in cities worldwide. The data suggests that the significant rise in temperatures in and around major cities is due to the Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect in response to population growth and development.

articles.title: Exposure to mining fossil fuel linked to ALS, new research finds
articles.author: ABC News
articles.summary: A pollutant from fossil fuels has been linked to an increased risk of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) according to new research. It is caused by CO2 from fossil fuel emissions.    It is a major pollutant of CO2 found in fossil fuels.

articles.title: Planning for bushfires could be the difference between life and death
articles.summary: Authorities are warning of a heightened bushfire danger in parts of South Australia, Victoria and Western Australia. East coast is advised to stay on alert as well as the north-eastern states of Victoria and New South Wales are also on high alert.

articles.title: Goodbye 'false autumn', hello 'mast year' - here's what it means
articles.author: Sky News
articles.summary: The UK's hottest summer on record has triggered a "mast year" when trees and shrubs produce an unusually large number of fruits and nuts like acorns, conkers and berries. It's goodbye 'false autumn' and hello 'mast year'.

articles.title: Climate change linked to nearly 100,000 heatwave deaths in 2023: study
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Unprecedented heatwaves in 2023 caused 178,486 excess deaths worldwide, equivalent to 23 deaths per million. Southern Europe recorded the highest 2023 heatwave death rate at 120 per million, followed by Eastern and Western Europe. Heatwaves occurred during the hottest year on record, 1.45 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Earth Talk: Global warming and eye problems?
articles.author: The Brunswick News
articles.summary: There's a connection between global warming and increased eye problems for people with eye problems, according to EarthTalk's EarthTalk.com.  For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 909090 or visit a local Samaritans branch or click here for details.

articles.title: Farmer says northern food bowl a 'pipe dream' amid changing climate
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Farmers are close to abandoning the dream of a food bowl in northern Australia, as the region is nearing its "thermal limits" for cropping and cattle.    The region is near the limits for croppers and cattle, according to an expert.

articles.title: New Protections For New Zealand's Oldest Marine Park Become Law
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: There is an urgent need for legislative protections for Aotearoa New Zealand's oldest marine park. State of the Gulf reports have shown the ongoing state of environmental decline across the Gulf and the need for greater legislative protections.   .

articles.title: SA municipalities get high-resolution data to tackle climate hazards
articles.author: Mail Guardian South Africa
articles.summary: South Africa's municipalities are on the frontline of climate change. Local governments have lacked credible, policy-relevant climate science to inform responses at sub-national level. Sub-national fact sheets can be used to understand how climate hazards will affect South Africa in a warmer world.

articles.title: Ocean heatwaves are breaking Earth's hidden climate engine
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Marine heatwaves can jam the ocean's natural carbon conveyor belt, preventing carbon from reaching the deep sea. Researchers studying two major heatwaves in the U.S. are concerned about the impact on the climate.      Â

articles.title: Inhalers for asthma, COPD are climate change contributors, study finds
articles.author: CBS News
articles.summary: "These emissions drive global warming, exacerbating the very respiratory conditions inhalers are meant to relieve," according to the researchers. "They are harmful to human health."       .   "They cause global warming"   and "they cause respiratory problems".

articles.title: Climate Change Linked To Nearly 100,000 Deaths From 2023 Heatwaves, Global Study Finds
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: There will be nearly 100,000 deaths from 2023's unprecedented heatwaves linked to human-induced climate change, according to an Australian-led global study. The study was published in the journal "The International Journal of Climatology".

articles.title: GCC experts meet in Oman to build resilient cities
articles.author: Muskat Daily
articles.summary: The City Resilience Forum for Climate Change and Major Incidents opened in Muscat on Monday. It brings together experts from Oman and Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries to exchange experiences and enhance preparedness for climate-related hazards and major emergencies. The three-day forum is open to the public.

articles.title: Climate change may create 'ecological trap' for species who can't adapt
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Warming climate means winters in Ohio aren't as cold as they were a few decades ago, according to the National Weather Service. The autumn days are getting shorter, but winters are not as cold now as they used to be, the weather service reports.

articles.title: Ghana urged to establish culture of resilience to tackle climate change
articles.author: Ghana Business News
articles.summary: Dr Godfred Seidu Jasaw is the Chairman of the Parliamentary Select Committee on Food, Agriculture and Cocoa Affairs. He has called on Ghanaians to cultivate a culture of resilience to protect the environment, adapt to realities of climate change and safeguard Ghana's future.

articles.title: Caribbean island residents ask court to order Dutch state to take climate action
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: Residents of the Dutch-Caribbean told a court on Tuesday that climate is getting worse in the region. The court is hearing the case in The Hague today.       .   in the Hague, the court will hear the case tomorrow.

articles.title: Experts warn biofuels not a long-term solution for shipping
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Biofuels are not a long-term solution for decarbonising, according to experts advising Pacific states at the International Maritime Organization (IMO).   .   i.e. biofuels do not meet the needs of decarbonisation.

articles.title: Russia acting as 'brake' on efforts to combat global warming
articles.summary: A new Greenpeace report documents how Russia's environmental policies and practices are causing global harm. The report is titled Fossil Fuel Empire: The Environment of Post-2022 Russia and the Kremlin's Threat to Domestic and Global Stability and Sustainability. The Kremlin's need to maintain Russia's war machine is overriding any concerns about the damage done to ecosystems. Deforestation is among the top five environmental concerns among Russians.
